channel.title: Comments on: QCachegrind ( KCachegrind ) on Mac OS X

item.title: By: Matt
item.dc:creator: Matt
item.description: Note: If you copy pasted the line "export PATH=”$PATH:/usr/local/bin”" you might need to replace the quote characters.
item.content:encoded: Note: If you copy pasted the line “export PATH=”$PATH:/usr/local/bin”” you might need to replace the quote characters.

item.title: By: Asped
item.dc:creator: Asped
item.description: Thank you Motin! This one works for me on El Capitan.
item.content:encoded: Thank you Motin! This one works for me on El Capitan.

item.title: By: Greg H.
item.dc:creator: Greg H.
item.description:
Motin's clever trick works (and I'm using macports, not homebrew), but keep in mind that you'll have to convert the curly quotes that this blogging platform inserted back to standard quotes. This applies to both the single and double quotes. And of course you may have to proceed the "mv", "echo" and "chmod" commands with "sudo ".
Thanks!
item.content:encoded:
Motin’s clever trick works (and I’m using macports, not homebrew), but keep in mind that you’ll have to convert the curly quotes that this blogging platform inserted back to standard quotes. This applies to both the single and double quotes. And of course you may have to proceed the “mv”, “echo” and “chmod” commands with “sudo “.

Thanks!

item.title: By: Joseph Scott
item.dc:creator: Joseph Scott
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/2013/07/03/qcachegrind-kcachegrind-on-mac-os-x/#comment-4067">Motin</a>.
Good to know, thanks.

item.title: By: Motin
item.dc:creator: Motin
item.description:
This does no longer work in OSX El Capitan due to System Integration Protection: sudo ln -s /usr/local/bin/dot /usr/bin/dot
Workaround: $ cd /Applications/qcachegrind.app/Contents/MacOS $ mv qcachegrind qcachegrind.bin $ echo '#!/bin/bash export PATH="$PATH:/usr/local/bin" $(dirname $0)/qcachegrind.bin exit 0' > qcachegrind $ chmod +x qcachegrind
Then start qcachegrind as usual.
item.content:encoded:
This does no longer work in OSX El Capitan due to System Integration Protection:
sudo ln -s /usr/local/bin/dot /usr/bin/dot

Workaround:
$ cd /Applications/qcachegrind.app/Contents/MacOS
$ mv qcachegrind qcachegrind.bin
$ echo ‘#!/bin/bash
export PATH=”$PATH:/usr/local/bin”
$(dirname $0)/qcachegrind.bin
exit 0’ > qcachegrind
$ chmod +x qcachegrind

Then start qcachegrind as usual.

item.title: By: Bill Torpey
item.dc:creator: Bill Torpey
item.description:
Anupam -- thanks for that! Love cachegrind, but hate building it -- this is great.
One thing -- it looks like you still need to follow the instructions from https://gist.github.com/justfalter/1029580#file-how_to_install_qcachegrind_on_osx-txt about linking to dot if you want graphs: After installing dot (e.g., brew install graphviz
# By default, Graphviz installs dot to /usr/local/bin/dot, which qcachgrind.app # might not find since /usr/local/bin isn't in PATH by default (I think). In order # to ensure that my graphs render, I created a symlink from /usr/bin/dot to /usr/local/bin/dot: sudo ln -s /usr/local/bin/dot /usr/bin/dot
item.content:encoded:
Anupam — thanks for that! Love cachegrind, but hate building it — this is great.

One thing — it looks like you still need to follow the instructions from https://gist.github.com/justfalter/1029580#file-how_to_install_qcachegrind_on_osx-txt about linking to dot if you want graphs:
After installing dot (e.g.,
brew install graphviz

# By default, Graphviz installs dot to /usr/local/bin/dot, which qcachgrind.app
# might not find since /usr/local/bin isn’t in PATH by default (I think). In order
# to ensure that my graphs render, I created a symlink from /usr/bin/dot to /usr/local/bin/dot:
sudo ln -s /usr/local/bin/dot /usr/bin/dot

item.title: By: Anupam
item.dc:creator: Anupam
item.description: You can use homebrew to do this: brew install qcachegrind
item.content:encoded:
You can use homebrew to do this:
brew install qcachegrind

item.title: By: Alex
item.dc:creator: Alex
item.description: To clarify: 1. Install Qt opensource for mac (browser for release at http://download.qt-project.org/official_releases/qt/4.8/4.8.5/) 2. Add the following lines to .bash_profile export QTDIR=$HOME/Qt/5.4/clang_64 export PATH=$QTDIR/bin:$PATH 3. Clone repo git clone https://github.com/dtjm/kcachegrind.git cd kcachegrind/qcachegrind 4. In new terminal (to make path above available) session build .app: qmake -spec 'macx-g++'; make 5. Launch qcachegrind.app
item.content:encoded:
To clarify:
1. Install Qt opensource for mac (browser for release at http://download.qt-project.org/official_releases/qt/4.8/4.8.5/)
2. Add the following lines to .bash_profile
export QTDIR=$HOME/Qt/5.4/clang_64
export PATH=$QTDIR/bin:$PATH
3. Clone repo
git clone https://github.com/dtjm/kcachegrind.git
cd kcachegrind/qcachegrind
4. In new terminal (to make path above available) session build .app:
qmake -spec ‘macx-g++’; make
5. Launch qcachegrind.app
